title: Scrap metal dealer in £4m fight with a private jet company that has a number of famous clients
text:
A multi-millionaire scrap metal dealer has launched a £4million court claim against a private jet company that has boasted F1 champion Lewis Hamilton and Sir Philip Green among its clients.

The High Court action, which is expected to be heard in January, centres on a 1992 Bombardier Challenger 601 that Andre Serruys bought in 2007.

He claims that Gama Aviation overcharged him for managing the £2million plane and also failed to maintain the jet which he says led to it being written off.

Court claim: Andre Serruys says Gama Aviation overcharged him. (Stock image)

Serruys, whose personal wealth was once estimated at £100million, lives in Stanfield Hall, a £3 million moated mansion near Wymondham, Norfolk.

His father Harry, who died in 2005, built up the family's metal recycling business Easco before selling it to Sita, an offshoot of French waste giant Suez.

In 2008, it was revealed that Andre Serruys was being sued by Sita, who accused Easco of having manipulated accounts and inflated turnover prior to the sale.

It is understood that the action was eventually withdrawn.

Gama Aviation declined to comment.
